stem: The nurse is reviewing the client's chart and recent assessments. Based on the information provided, indicate the most appropriate interdisciplinary referral for each identified client need.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 14:00 SBAR for Ms. Eleanor Vance, DOB 03/15/1942. Situation: Ms. Vance is a 82-year-old female admitted for exacerbation of dysphagia following a recent stroke 3 weeks ago. Background: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and controlled type 2 diabetes. Stroke affected right side motor function. Assessment: Patient is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Speech is slurred, and she exhibits difficulty swallowing thin liquids, coughing frequently during meals. Right upper extremity weakness is noted with limited range of motion. Fine motor skills impaired in right hand. Vitals stable: BP 130/80, HR 78, RR 18, SpO2 96% on room air. 16:00 - Patient reports difficulty buttoning her shirt and using utensils during lunch. 18:00 - Noted patient attempting to ambulate to the bathroom independently. She demonstrated an unsteady gait and required assistance to prevent a fall. 20:00 - Patient expresses frustration about her decreased independence and limited mobility. Reports feeling isolated from family. Plan: Continue monitoring swallowing function and risk for aspiration. Encourage use of adaptive equipment during meals. Consult with speech therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy for comprehensive evaluation and treatment plan. Social worker consult ordered to address psychosocial needs. Encourage family visits and social interaction. Provide emotional support and education regarding stroke recovery and rehabilitation.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Elderly female, alert and oriented x3. Neuro: Cranial nerves II-XII intact. Speech slurred. Right-sided weakness noted. Motor: Decreased strength in right upper extremity. Limited range of motion in right shoulder and elbow. Fine motor skills impaired in right hand. Musculoskeletal: Unsteady gait. Requires assistance with ambulation. Swallowing: Exhibits difficulty swallowing thin liquids. Coughs frequently during meals.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Monitor swallowing function and risk for aspiration.
  • Encourage use of adaptive equipment during meals.
  • Consult with speech therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy for comprehensive evaluation and treatment plan.
  • Social worker consult ordered to address psychosocial needs.
  • Encourage family visits and social interaction.
  • Provide emotional support and education regarding stroke recovery and rehabilitation.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
• Metoprolol 25mg PO BID
  • Atorvastatin 20mg PO daily
  • Metformin 500mg PO BID
  • Docusate 100mg PO daily

rows.text: Difficulty swallowing thin liquids and coughing during meals.
Impaired fine motor skills in right hand and difficulty using utensils.
Unsteady gait and risk of falls.
Expresses frustration about decreased independence and isolation.

rationale.correct: Speech Therapist: A speech therapist evaluates and treats swallowing disorders (dysphagia). Occupational Therapist: An occupational therapist assists patients in improving their ability to perform activities of daily living, including fine motor skills needed for eating and dressing. Physical Therapist: A physical therapist focuses on improving mobility, balance, and gait to prevent falls. Social Worker: A social worker addresses psychosocial needs, provides emotional support, and connects patients with resources.
rationale.incorrect: Consider the primary deficit described in the row and determine the healthcare professional whose scope of practice directly addresses that deficit. Think about the specific skills and interventions provided by each discipline (speech therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and social work).

answerBreakdown.text: Difficulty swallowing thin liquids and coughing during meals.
answerBreakdown.rationale: A speech therapist specializes in evaluating and treating swallowing disorders (dysphagia). They can assess the patient's swallowing mechanism, identify the cause of the difficulty, and implement strategies to improve swallowing safety and efficiency, reducing the risk of aspiration.

answerBreakdown.text: Impaired fine motor skills in right hand and difficulty using utensils.
answerBreakdown.rationale: An occupational therapist focuses on helping patients regain or improve their ability to perform activities of daily living. They address fine motor skills, hand coordination, and the use of adaptive equipment to enable patients to eat, dress, and perform other daily tasks independently.

answerBreakdown.text: Unsteady gait and risk of falls.
answerBreakdown.rationale: A physical therapist specializes in improving mobility, balance, and gait. They can assess the patient's balance and strength, develop a plan to improve their walking ability, and provide exercises and assistive devices to reduce the risk of falls.

answerBreakdown.text: Expresses frustration about decreased independence and isolation.
answerBreakdown.rationale: A social worker addresses the psychosocial needs of patients and their families. They can provide emotional support, counseling, and connect patients with resources to address feelings of frustration, isolation, and loss of independence. They also facilitate communication between the patient, family, and healthcare team.

clinicalPearls: Interdisciplinary collaboration is essential for comprehensive patient care, especially in complex cases like stroke recovery.
Accurate assessment and identification of patient needs are crucial for appropriate referrals.
Each member of the interdisciplinary team brings unique expertise to address different aspects of the patient's needs.

questionTrap.trap: Students may confuse the roles of occupational and physical therapists, especially when both motor skills and mobility are affected.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize that occupational therapists focus on activities of daily living and fine motor skills, while physical therapists focus on gross motor skills, mobility, and balance.
